headline.en-US: Promotion campaign for Britvic's J2O winter specials

content.value: Promotion campaign for Britvic's J2O winter specials
Transitioning the website for this large engineering firm from simple to spectacular and letting the images do the talking.

Arup are on of the largest Engineering firms in the world and have been involved in many of the most recognizable buildings in the world such as the Sydney Opera House and London Eye. Moving from a standard text-heavy corporate website to a modern image driven website had many challenges.

With the website being fully CMS controlled, many of the pages contained large amounts of image components containing high resolution content. This meant that optimization was important on both the front and back end of the website. Image lazy loading techniques improved the perceived performance to the user, while ImageProcessor was used on the back end to provide compressed images at the correct size for each scenario.

Having thousands of pages of content divided into even larger amounts of components and sub-components also brought more challenges. A live search component was created to help content discovery using Sitecore as a REST endpoint. The large volume of
Projects
were categorized into searchable categories accessed with a Javascript interactive search component.
CMC Markets is a large London based financial trading platform with offerings such as CFD's and Spread Betting.

This project involved creating a mobile version of thier current desktop client. The platform was built in pure ES6 Javascript, however it used some features of AngularJS such as dependency injection.

The challange of this project was the scale and size of the application. With thousands of complex components working together in application, it required a deep level of understanding of what each and every feature was doing and how it would affect the new mobile application.
Features such as persistent state between sessions and garbage collection introduced new complexities in addition to the live nature of fiancial rates.
Happiest was a wellbeing themed social network that allowed users to connect with businesses and gain rewards for the products they buy.

Many of the social features on this website are now common in todays internet however in 2012 they were considered more advanced and innovative features. Happiest were one of many tech start ups at the time looking to become the next big name in the social web.

Features such as a live updating feed, followers, status updates and interactions with friends gave this application strong foundations as a good social media website, with a wellbeing journal feature giving this a unique selling point. The next direction for the application was to move into the loyalty and rewards market with features such as badges, acheivements and an employer facing admin UI added to the offering.

The application was a single page Javascript web app powered by a REST API and Postgres database. This was back in 2012, so many of the fancy frameworks that have become staples for front and back end development did not exist. The code base was mostly a custom implementation that was built with technologies such as PHP, Handlebars templates and Underscore JS.
A modern apparoach to developing Wordpress sites using React components to create a clean and stylish website for a garage.

The new Gutenberg editor in Wordpress 5 has modernized the approach to developing with Wordpress. In the past I have always liked working with Wordpress, and clients have always found it easy to use. It meets so many requirements for small businesses wanting a website to showcase thier products at a low cost, but it feels dated from a developers perspective. Working with PHP, no modern build tools and an unpredicatable plugin ecosystem make it challanging in all the wrong ways.

Gutenberg Blocks have helped this by allowing developers to use React to create components for both the front end and Admin UI. These plug ins make customizing the admin experience easy and components re-usable accross the templates. using React opens up the doors for all other modern tooling such as Webpack and Typescript.
Making use of modern web technologies to create a visually attractive portfolio website that is fast, responsive and easy to update.

Many new techonlogies have emerged over recent years making use of data provided by a Headless CMS. This allows the data to be edited and created seperate to the code. I chose Contentful for this as I am a big fan of thier UI, which looks good and is easy to use. It also has a lot of great features such as GraphQL support, generated Types, easy integration into other tools and a great image API.

Developing a site in this way is much cleaner than the old monolithic approach to CMS. A webhook is added to Contentful which will trigger a new build of the website on each publish. Netlify is used to host the website as this will build and deploy each time a new publish or code change happens. Again this is very simple and easy to set up, reducing many hours of complex config and reducing the need for any developer input in future.

Gatsby and React are used to build the front end. React is used with additional technolgies such as Storybook and Emotion to allow component driven development. Gatsby will turn this complex web application into a static website which allows users to get fast page loads and improves search engine indexing of pages.
An ambitious, visualy stunning website created for drinks manufacturer Britvic to promote thier winter range.

This project was purely a front end website build for two new drinks products. As you can see from the screenshots below, this involved a combination of a lot of high-resoltion images along with lots of information about the products.

The challenge with this website was making it fully responsive while retaining the ambitious deisgn that involved very precise placing of assets. This was a great CSS/SASS challenge and was a big success for the brand.
Home Group are a housing association and charity that have been active in the UK for over 80 years.

In recent times they have invested in modernizing their techology offerings for customers, which included an online payments management application. This involved making use of technolgies such as React and Node to create a full-stack Typescript application hosted in the cloud.

The biggest challenge was the amount of older system that sit between the new application and the data it needs. Some creative solutions were put in place to get around the limitations of some of these systems.
Creating a new payments journey for one of the biggest names in the Aviation industry.

I worked as part of a large project to give new look and feel to what was at the time a dated and corperate looking website. The project involved making use of modern Javascript and CSS to create a better customer experience on the payment page and the preceeding payment flow.
During my time at British Airways I also worked on other areas of the website, adding new features to Managing Bookings and Search.
Hive is an employee engagement platform that allows businesses to connect with their employees.
Features of the application are surveying, recognition and the ability to leave anonymouse suggestions.

The platform is based in the Cloud and makes use of many different cloud services such as Batch, Lambda and micro service applications. The user interacts with a modern React application based on Typescirpt making use of many new technologies such as Hooks and Emotion.

Micro front ends are used to create smaller applications within the larger container application. This can support seperate applications for the large administrator dashboard and smaller employee facing pages.

headline.en-US: See how this porfolio website was created

content.value: See how this
Portfolio Website
was created
This website is split into two parts, a front end and a back end. This how it was built and what technology was used.

This page that you are viewing now is created using Next.JS to generate the page on build using Netlify. It was originally built ising Gatsby and then migrated to Next.JS as I believe it has become a much better tool.

The website components are created using React, fully typed with Typescript. The content for the page lives in Contentful, which allows me to edit these pages without having to write any code. I have used several modern headless CMS tools in the past, but I keep coming back to Contentful due to it's fantastic UI and great integration with coding tools.

To style the website I have used custom styles using Emotion Styled Components. I have built some of the components on Chakra UI which gives me benefit of great base level components without opinionated styling. I have used this over creating everything from scratch as a time saver, as it comes fully typed and feature rich.

I have also used the Netlify platform to create serverless functions, which are Lambdas integrated into Netlify. This is used for retrieving the music data on the home page which comes from the Last FM API, getting my top 3 albums for the last 3 months. I store the result of this in a Mongo Database on Atlas, to give me some caching benefits and to remove the reliance on an unknown API. It is updated each week, and the cache is used by the frontend.

This website has been moved between several versions and technologies, dating back to 2013. Traditionally I have used a Node API which I am slowly moving to Lambdas. I still have the Node API running now, which is only used for the contact form. It is built using Node and Typescript, compiled into a Docker container.

headline.en-US: A re-usable Wedding website template created with React for Headless CMS

content.value: A re-usable Wedding website template created with React for Headless CMS
This website is an adaptable and re-usable template styled for a Wedding website.

It was created using Netlify CMS, however it can easily by adapted to use any other Headless CMS. The components are all created using React and Styled Components, using configuration from the CMS to customize the display.

headline.en-US: Leading the Javascript team for the back end of global fashion brand Boohoo

content.value: Supporting the back end of a global fashion brand
Leading a team supporting and developing three large applications to help progress the back end systems of major fashion brand Boohoo.

This involved working with full stack applications using Node, React and AWS. The applications are part of the back end systems used by the company to deal with raising orders, auditing suppliers and shipping stock the warehouses.

As a Technical Lead this role invovled a lot of technical refinement and improving the technology stack. As part of this is have transitioned the applications onto new technologies such as moving to Vite for front end builds, Typescript migration and setting up cloud infrstructure such as Cognito and AppConfig.
Moving a popular flooring store from a legacy platform to modern Javascript technology.
Moving a popular flooring store from a legacy platform to modern Javascript technology.

The old application was built over a long period of time on a monolith system using legacy tools that caused a lot of maintenance issues. My role was to rebuild the product pages using Next.js, with Contentful as a data source. The back end of the new system was moved to a new microservices API built with Nest JS and GraphQL.

Another app was also created to migrate products from the old system to new one. This was created to be a Lambda thar could run on a schedule or via a Webhook. Products were fetched and transformed using RxJs.
